Art. 4.220
Obligation to preserve in favour of the next generation 
Property which fathers and mothers are entitled to dispose of may be given or bequeathed by them, in whole or in part, to one or more of their children, with the obligation to preserve it so that it may be transmitted to children born or to be born, in the first degree only, of the said donees.   In 
the event of death without children, the provision made by the deceased by gift or will, for the benefit of one or more of his brothers or sisters, of all or part of the property not reserved by law in his succession, with the obligation to preserve it so that it may pass to the children born or to be born, to the first degree only, of the said beneficiary brothers or sisters, 
is valid.
Paragraphs 1 and 2 are valid only insofar as the obligation to preserve is for the benefit of all the children born and unborn of the encumbered person, without exception or preference as to age or sex.
If, in the above cases, the person subject to the charge of conservation in favour of his children dies, leaving children in the first degree and descendants of a predeceased child, the latter receive, by substitution, the portion of the predeceased child.
